basically how does it work that's it's always a question about you know how does the Lex part work so the goal of a
Lex bot is to get specific data from your user so that it can give you the
output you need to drive the next step of the operation so it does it against
this this information from the user in the form of a concept called slots so let's walk through this with an example
let's say you've got a bot which says basically it's about to let someone book
a hotel now to book a hotel room at a bare minimum you need to know the
location so the city in this case you need to know the check-in date and you need to know the number of days someone
wants to stay in in that hotel room so what you would do is you would define three slots in this case you will define
a slot of type City which is a built-in built-in slot type that we provide you
provide us you provide a slot for check-in date which is again a date and
then you provide number of days which is a number type which is again provided so then you plug in the slots into what's
called an intent the goal of an intent is to conduct the conversation so it is
basically think of it as a state machine that will then walk the user through the various prompts that need to be
triggered to collect all this data so for example an intent would be something like and instead could be triggered with
something like you know book me a hotel room let's start of the conversation and then the appropriate intent gets
identified by the bot and starts up and then what the intent will do is based on the slots you've provided and
the priorities you provide it it'll prompt the user with specific questions to get the information it needs so just
walking through this example we have on the screen the intent that would be triggered is the book Hotel intent and
the first question it asks is where the location of the the hotel so you specify
the city in this case and then it moves on to give me the check-in date and then moves on to number of days once you once
the bot has all this information once it's completed all of this it's come it's worth of this state it has
collected all this state it then triggers the fulfillment step which which basically lets you either invoke a
lambo function which they information with the information it's create collected or you can hand back the
parameters to your application which then lets you coordinate and do
whatever you want in the application at that point in time so for the purposes of the session will focus on the second
phase the second part which is the client side fulfillment mode one important thing I wanted to point out
was the intent to create and reusable they are not tied to an application so
benefit of this is you can train an intent in a certain application and reuse it in a different application and
you get you get the you get the you get the learning and the enhancements that the intent has acquired while it's being
used across multiple applications cool so let's go ahead and create a Lex bot
